title: 107_s3140
content: The Act may be cited as the "Prevention and Recovery of Missing Children Act of 2002". The Act, known as the "Prevention and Recovery of Missing Children Act of 2002," highlights the importance of an improved registration system for sex offenders and predators targeting children. It emphasizes the need for timely cooperation among law enforcement agencies to prevent and resolve crimes, especially in cases of non-family abductions. The National Crime Information Center (NCIC) database is crucial for sharing information among over 16,000 law enforcement agencies to ensure the safe return of missing children. In abduction homicide cases, 74% of children are dead within 3 hours and 91% are killed within 24 hours, emphasizing the urgency of ensuring the safe return of missing children. SEC. 3. MISSING CHILD REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Amends the Crime Control Act of 1990 to ensure no removal of missing person entries based solely on age. Requires reporting within 2 hours. Amendment to the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 requires individuals to provide registration information including name, address, employer details, vehicle information, and student enrollment. Amendment to the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 now includes requirements for obtaining fingerprints, a photograph, and a DNA sample for individuals, with specific provisions for incarcerated persons. State procedures for registering individuals moving to another state must ensure prompt availability of information, verification of registry data every 90 days, and notification of changes in personal information to local law enforcement agencies. The amendment to the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 now includes requirements for obtaining fingerprints, a photograph, and a DNA sample for individuals required to register under this section. State procedures mandate that local law enforcement obtain a photograph at initial registration and annually for verification throughout the registration term. The amendment to the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 now includes requirements for obtaining fingerprints, a photograph, and a DNA sample for individuals required to register under this section. States must designate failure to comply with registration and verification requirements as a felony, allowing for immediate arrest warrants. Compliance failures are considered ongoing offenses for statute of limitations purposes. Failure to register each changed registry information item is considered a separate offense.
